org.ambraproject.rhino.rest.controller.abstr

Class RestController

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ambraproject.rhino.rest.controller.abstr.RestController
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConfigurationReadController, ContentRepoController, DoiBasedCrudController, IngestibleZipController, JournalCrudController, TaxonomyController, TestCrossrefController, UserCrudController

    public abstract class RestController
extends Object
    Controller that sends HTTP responses to RESTful requests.

    • Method Detail

      • getFullPathVariable

        protected static String getFullPathVariable(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                         boolean optional,
                         String namespace)
        Retrieve a RESTful argument that consists of the entire request URL after a namespace prefix. The namespace prefix consists of one or more URI path elements that the API defines as a prefix for a class of RESTful "nouns" and must end with a slash (for example, "/article/"). The request's URI must contain the given namespace prefix: everything before the namespace (typically the path to the webapp, or nothing) is ignored, and everything after the namespace is the return value.

        This is essentially doing the work of a PathVariable annotated parameter, but Spring does not seem to support PathVariables that span multiple URI components across slashes. So, if we want to treat a value that contains slashes (such as a DOI, which is itself a nested URI) as a single variable, we have to parse it from the request URI string ourselves.

        Parameters:
        request - the HTTP request for a REST action
        optional - if true, null will be returned if no additional path exists after the namespace; if false, IllegalArgumentException will be thrown if this is the case
        namespace - the namespace in which the request was received @return the contents of the request path after the namespace prefix
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the request URI does not start with the namespace or if the namespace does not end with a slash, and optional is false

      • reportOk

        protected org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<Object> reportOk()
        Report that a RESTful operation succeeded. The returned object (if returned from a RequestMapping) will cause the REST response to indicate an "OK" HTTP status and have an empty response body.
        Returns:
        a response indicating "OK"

      • reportCreated

        protected org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<Object> reportCreated()
        Report that a RESTful operation to create an entity succeeded. The returned object (if returned from a RequestMapping) will cause the REST response to indicate a "Created" HTTP status and have an empty response body.
        Returns:
        a response indicating "Created"

      • reportCreated

        protected org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<String> reportCreated(String identifier)
        Report that a RESTful operation to create an entity succeeded. The returned object (if returned from a RequestMapping) will cause the REST response to indicate a "Created" HTTP status and provide the identifier of the created object to the client.
        Parameters:
        identifier - the identifier of the created object
        Returns:
        a response indicating "Created"

      • reportClientError

        @ExceptionHandler(value=RestClientException.class)
public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<String> reportClientError(RestClientException e)
        Report an error condition to the REST client. The brief error message is sent as the response body, with the response code specified when the exception object was created. The stack trace is not included because we generally expect the client to fix the error with a simple change to input.
        Parameters:
        e - the exception that Spring wants to handle
        Returns:
        the RESTful response body

      • reportRequestError

        @ExceptionHandler(value=org.springframework.web.bind.ServletRequestBindingException.class)
public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<String> reportRequestError(org.springframework.web.bind.ServletRequestBindingException srbe)
        Exception handler for exceptions thrown by the Spring MVC framework when incoming requests cannot be matched with the @RequestParam-annotated parameters. For example, if a request is missing a required parameter, or the types do not match, this handler will be invoked. This method returns a 405 status code to the client instead of a 500.
        Parameters:
        srbe - exception from the Spring framework
        Returns:
        ResponseEntity encapsulating a 405 return code and an informative error message

      • reportServerError

        @ExceptionHandler(value=java.lang.Exception.class)
public org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity<String> reportServerError(Exception e)
        Display a server-side error to the rest client. This is meant generally to handle bugs and configuration errors. Because this is assumed to be caused by programmer error, the stack trace is sent in the request body.
        Parameters:
        e - the exception that Spring wants to handle
        Returns:
        the RESTful response body

      • getParameters

        protected static com.google.common.collect.ImmutableListMultimap<String,String> getParameters(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request)

      • booleanParameter

        protected static boolean booleanParameter(String parameter)
        Interpret a request parameter value as a boolean value. The argument should be a String supplied by a RequestParam-supplied value.

        The parameter is generally expected to be a flag-style URI parameter. For example, the client sends a request to http://example.com/api?foo and the controller method has an argument @RequestParam("foo") String fooParam. Then fooParam would have the value "". If the client leaves ?foo off the URI, then fooParam would be null. Hence, this method interprets null as false and non-null strings in general, including the empty string, as true.

        However, the string "false" is (case-insensitively) interpreted as boolean false, so the client has the option of sending to http://example.com/api?foo=true or http://example.com/api?foo=false and getting sensible behavior. (This is especially handy for client scripts whose authors want to pass actual boolean primitives, not strings, to their request library.)

        Contrast Boolean.valueOf(String), which converts null and the empty string to false. Also contrast @RequestParam on a boolean argument, which expects "true" or "false" as a value and rejects other input.

        Parameters:
        parameter - a request parameter
        Returns:
        the parameter interpreted as a boolean value

      • setLastModifiedHeader

        protected void setLastModifiedHeader(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse response,
                         Date lastModified)
        Sets the Last-Modified header of the response appropriately.
        Parameters:
        response - HttpServletResponse
        lastModified - date to set the header to

      • checkIfModifiedSince

        protected boolean checkIfModifiedSince(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                           Date lastModified)
        Checks for the presence of an "If-Modified-Since" header on the request. If it exists, returns true iff lastModified is after the date in the header. That is, returns true if we should send content, and false if a 304 Not Modified response is appropriate.
        Parameters:
        request - HttpServletRequest
        lastModified - last modified date of the entity being requested
        Returns:
        true if we should send the entity, false if we should send a 304 response
